meanings.def: a long narrow piece of paper, metal, cloth, etc.
examples: a strip of material
Cut the meat into strips.
The wallpaper can then be torn off in strips.
a card with a magnetic strip on the back
Cut a strip of paper 12cm wide.
His hands were tied behind his back with a strip of fabric.
a narrow strip of leather
grilled chicken strips

meanings.def: a long narrow area of land, sea, etc.
examples: the Gaza Strip
a tiny strip of garden
The islands are separated by a narrow strip of water.

meanings.def: the uniform that is worn by the members of a sports team when they are playing
examples: Juventus in their famous black and white strip
the team’s away strip (= that they use when playing games away from home)

meanings.def: an act of taking your clothes off, especially in a sexually exciting way and in front of an audience
examples: to do a strip
a strip show

meanings.def: a street that has many shops, stores, restaurants, etc. along it
examples: Sunset Strip

meanings.def: a series of drawings inside boxes that tell a story and are often published in newspapers
to speak angrily to somebody who has done something wrong

idioms.idiom: tear somebody off a strip | tear a strip off somebody
idioms.def: to speak angrily to somebody who has done something wrong

meanings.def: to take off all or most of your clothes or another person’s clothes
examples: I stripped and washed myself all over.
They ordered us to strip and lie down on the grass.
strip down to something She stripped down to her underwear.
strip (something) off We stripped off and ran down to the water.
She stripped off her clothes and got into bed.
strip somebody (to something) He stood there stripped to the waist (= he had no clothes on the upper part of his body).
strip somebody + adj. He was stripped naked and left in a cell.
Office workers stripped down to their shirtsleeves in the heatwave.
He stripped off his shirt.

meanings.def: to take off your clothes as a form of entertainment; to perform a striptease
to remove a layer from something, especially so that it is completely exposed
examples: strip something (off) Strip off all the existing paint.
After the guests had gone, I stripped all the beds (= removed all the sheets in order to wash them).
strip A off/from B Deer had stripped all the bark off the tree.
strip B of A Deer had stripped the tree of its bark.

meanings.def: to remove all the things from a place and leave it empty
examples: strip something (out) We had to strip out all the old wiring and start again.
strip something away First, you need to strip away all the old plaster.
(figurative) The movie aims to strip away the lies surrounding Kennedy's life.
strip something + adj. Thieves had stripped the house bare.

meanings.def: to separate a machine, etc. into parts so that they can be cleaned or repaired
examples: He strips and cleans his rifle every morning.
They taught us how to strip down a car engine and put it back together again.

meanings.def: to take away property or honours from somebody, as a punishment
examples: He was disgraced and stripped of his title.
The president had been completely stripped of power.
